Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: FIND - On The Economic Viability of Network Architectures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet is a phenomenal success, but problems and weaknesses in
it have become apparent, and this has spurred a search for new
technologies and network architectures. Although technical innovation
will remain fundamental to the Internet's evolution, the importance of
this key infrastructure for society as a whole means that economic
aspects will be critical in determining what innovations are adopted.
This project, therefore, seeks to investigate -- both qualitatively
and quantitatively -- how economic factors mediate the eventual
success of new network architectures and technologies. Aspects of
interest include quantifying the benefits of virtualization in
enabling different levels of network integration; evaluating the
effect of a dominant incumbent (today's Internet) on emerging new
architectures; and devising models for quantifying the value of
architectural flexibility and openness in facilitating technology
adoption and service creation in the presence of market uncertainties.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research is in developing an
economic framework for reasoning about network technologies,
architecture alternatives and trade-offs. The goal is to inform the
design of new network architectures by accounting for both their
technical dimensions, and the economic mechanisms that will mediate
their success or failure. The broader impact of the project will be
in helping select network solutions that are likely to succeed in the
market place. The project will also foster a multi-disciplinary
curriculum involving economics, business and engineering perspectives.
This will both better prepare engineering students to succeed in a
world where understanding of economical forces is of paramount
importance, and promote interactions and collaboration among
engineering and business students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intent of this project was to develop a better understanding of how economic factors influence the design choices and the eventual success of networking technologies.  For example, why did the Internet succeed and what may affect its evolution?  The investigation was framed through key questions that permeate the main aspects of (network) technology development and deployment.  We highlight next the project’s scientific findings and their implications.  The project trained Ph.D. students and was used to involve undergraduate students into research through REUs.

Understanding network technology migration

Understanding why and how users migrate from one technology to another is of particular importance in networks, because the value of a network is closely coupled to how many users it has.  The migration from IPv4 to IPv6 provides a timely example of the challenges this poses.  The IPv4 protocol powered the Internet through its famous phases of commercialization and explosive growth.  But it has numerous defects (or at least limitations), and a successor protocol, IPv6, was standardized 16 years ago.  IPv6 is especially noteworthy for providing increased address space, a critical and limited resource with IPv4.  Yet in spite of the last large “free” block of IPv4 addresses having been recently (February 2011) allocated, as of today only a minute fraction (<0.5%) of the overall Internet is accessible over IPv6, to the great puzzlement and frustration of many Internet experts.

This work developed a fundamental understanding of when and how users may decide to migrate to a new network technology.  The results can help predict outcomes, e.g., can the incumbent be dislodged, will the two technologies co-exist for extended periods of time, etc.?  Additionally, these results provide quantitative guidelines for developing gateways that provide inter-operability across technologies, e.g., to allow new IPv6 users to access the current IPv4 Internet.  These guidelines reflect the results of the studies which proved to be at times counter-intuitive, with improving gateways occasionally disrupting a previously smooth transition; i.e., causing “boom-and-bust” cycles with users migrating back-and-forth between technologies.

In a follow-up effort, the Internet migration from IPv4 to IPv6 was specifically investigated.  The investigation confirmed the ambiguous role of gateways. 

Competition in a complex system of networks and service providers

The Internet is a complex system of many different types of agents operating with multiple interactions between them.  Game theoretic models were built that model competition among service providers and network providers.  They provide insights into incentives for service and network innovation.

When is one network better than two?

One measure of the Internet’s success is arguably that it has become the common platform for all communication services, i.e., from voice to video to web to grid computing.  There are obvious benefits to such convergence, but there are also potential disadvantages.  A network shared by multiple services must meet the needs of all of them, which often demands expensive features of little or no value to most services.

Models were developed that account for the complex interactions in economies and diseconomies of scope that arise when sharing a network between services.  The models identified an unexpected contributor to deciding when converged or separate networks are preferred, namely, the network’s ability to dynamically reallocate resources to meet unexpected demand.  This factor alone can drastically affect which of converged or separate networks is more efficient...
